I spent hours checking this and these methods seem to work.
I always wanted to play this game, so when I saw it on the store, I couldn't resist. I played more offline so the amount of time I've spent isn't shown. If you like star wars and age of empires 2 then you won't be dissapointed.

reviewText:
“When 900 years old, you reach… Look as good, you will not.”
- Yoda, Grand Master of the Jedi Order
Star Wars: Galactic Battlegrounds is a real-time strategy game, and was orginaly relased back in 2001.
Almost 15 years have already passed and of course right now game is very dated in every aspect.
It's important to say that developers used upgraded Genie Engine which was designed in order to create first Age of Empires.

After a very short time spent in this game you will realize that it has both - advantages and disadvantages tied to this game engine. Game interface, units upgrades, game balance, units AI, resource managment and even 4-tier tech levels are a clear copy/paste of what we know from Age of Empires 2.
This is just the same game when we speak about it's roots, and the only one diffirence is Star Wars license used during development. Layout has been re-skinned and developers implemented new campaigns inspired of course by Star Wars Universe.

The most important thing you might ask will sounds like: is this game still playable?
The answer is not simple and depends on what you expect. If you loved Age of Empires series and if you're a fan of Star Wars then for sure it will be a very interesting trip.
I still remember how bad this game was when Microsoft relased it. We (RTS fans) had too high hopes and thats why Galactic Batlegrounds was a huge disappointment.
But now? In 2016? It's funny but game became a better experience. Why? Because now you can experience it as a relic from the past, so expectations are lowered to minimum.
One thing for sure - if you still like old RTS games, then definietly you will like Star Wars: Galactic Battlegrounds as well.
Thanks for reading!

I highly recommend this game to any RTS fans. It's arguably the best Star Wars Strategy game out there.

reviewText:
One of my favoriite Star Wars games through the years. I have a cd version of this but like having a discless version to take on trips, now I have one more game to take on the road with my laptop. As for the review part:

Made on the same engine Age of Empires II, Star Wars Galaxies acts the same with with just a few differences. Maps, Units, and Gameplay act the same, but with a Space Motif. Unlike Age of Empires each unit has a unique style and look giving different style for each faction. There is even flying units that can go around all terrain allowing you to find hidden units and special easter eggs on several maps in the campaigns. I remember enjoying finding the characters from the movies and using them on the maps I found them to win the game. Though I am against cheating in games it is something neat to note that in Singleplayer you can find cheats that spawn units like the Death Star.

The game has aged well and even though it is a little buggy in this version to get running I find with a little help from the community guides and forums I have it running and without using a CD. Like all older games it just takes patience and a little know how to get things to work and this game is worth it.

So to wrap up this review it is a gem to find it on Steam. If you enjoy Real Time Strategy games and are willing to work to get it to run on a modern computer you will not be disappointed. I suggest installing the patch from the community guides to get it to run without messing with stuff in the installation folder.

reviewText:
I owned this game when it originally came out, so my hours on Steam don't reflect the hundreds of hours I put in as a kid.

tl;dr at the bottom, kind of like fruit in a delicious yogurt cup

SWGB is one of those games I keep reinstalling, no matter how much time goes by. It follows the classic format of Age of Empires II with some notable differences - from the cosmetic overhaul to the fact that basic infantry have blasters instead of swords - that make it stand out. These differences allow for a variety of viable strategies, from converting everything your enemy treasures with Jedi/Sith to creating an impregnable fortress and slowly expanding.

The AI is very retro in the sense that it's not metaphorically drooling on the floor. When I set campaign difficulty to hard, I forgot that it would actually pose a challenge and accidentally lost the man I needed to protect. When I set a standard game's difficulty to normal, I forgot that is normal for someone acquainted with the nature of the game and got mauled for being rusty.

There's a campaign for each faction. No, not just a campaign: a fully-voiced campaign. It can definitely get cheesy, but it's fun nonetheless.

The campaign isn't the main chunk of gameplay, though. It's mostly in the standard mode, which generates a map and offers an array of game modes that can even be played in singleplayer. If this isn't enough and you have a bit of a creative spark, there's an extensive map editor that allows for the placement of every prop, unit, and building in the game. It comes with the tools to make your creation feel less like a handmade map and more like a homemade campaign (such as modifying unit stats, changing possession of buildings, and even setting new win/loss conditions).

So far, all of this has been positive.  It's hard to be unbiased when you grew up on it. However, here's some things I've noticed that were a little offputting:

• The multiplayer matchmaking is long dead. There is a LAN function, but I haven't tested its functionality. I'd assume it still works.
• Graphics settings are limited, offering low, medium, and high settings and a selection of three 4:3 resolutions. There's no 4K, 2K, or even 1080p support (officially).
• Steam overlay doesn't appear to work.

tl;dr
If you haven't played it before and you like classic RTSes and Star Wars, you can't really go wrong with this entry. Just know that this isn't some fancy shmancy HD remaster; it's the same game that came out on November 9th, 2001.

reviewText:
This is an absolutely fantastic game - a classic of the RTS genre and it's such a shame that they never remade this game with modern graphics. If you love Star Wars or just RTS' in general, this is a game you will enjoy playing. Expect Age of Empires style mechanics and a wide variety of units designed to bring the pain. Quick note regarding the lore/canon - this game was made BEFORE Revenge of the Sith came out so the canonical sins can be forgiven (Most of the time the game simply glosses over the events of RotS anyway).

However, if you do not wish to mess around in the game files DO NOT BUY THIS GAME. It has been released in a horrific state:
1. You cannot launch it from Steam. For whatever reason, the Steam targeted executable only plays the opening movies and thats it (Workaround - simply rename 'Player.exe' to anything else and rename 'battlegrounds_x1.exe' to 'Player.exe').
2. The Clone Campaigns expansion does not work from the get-go. You have to find a patched version of the 'battlegrounds_x1.exe' online and replace the old one with it (Just search 'clone campaigns no cd patch' and grab version 1.1).
3. The music files are all missing, so there is no in-game music (menu music only). No idea whether that was deliberate or not but you can always have YouTube running whilst playing).
4. Without a widescreen patch the max resolution is 1280x720. Even with widescreen patches it's not 100% 1080p but its the best that can be done.
5. On newer OS' (I say 'newer', I mean Windows Vista and up) the DirectDraw render is bugged awfully. You need to patch the executable (again, I know) in order to get colours to work correctly (sometimes the game won't even start at all unless you patch it).

It's in a pretty poor state right now but the Discussions forums are really helpful. You shouldn't have to put in more than 10 minutes fixing time to get it to work.

Final Note: I have received reports that this game cannot be refunded for whatever reason. It's a risk you'll have to take.

So, in conclusion, this game is excellent to play but you'll need to invest your own time in order to get to that point. I do reviews based on my own experience and fun I've had already outweighs the initial tinkering I had to do to get the game to work.

reviewText:
I'm going to put this straight:

This game is THE ♥♥♥♥.

I played this game every day for hours on end as a kid, on my now non-existant Windows ME desktop (THAT certainly dates it, huh?). This game was beyond amazing then, and still holds up today.

It's a little wonky, being so old, but there are community-made patches for some of the issues. A few of the patches introduce a few issues of their own, but they're beyond minor.

This game, is summed up in this short sentence:

Age of Empires: Star Wars Edition.

Yep, that's this game. But it has a helluva lot more to it than that, such as improved AI (sometimes), more units, civs, and structures, including air-units, new map-making materials, such as making space-stations, asteroids, or cloud cities. and new, unique campaigns of never-before-seen stories taking place in the timelines of Episodes I, II, IV, V, and VI, because III hadn't even begun filming at the time of this game's release.

The game is solid, if a bit aged. The graphics leave much to be desired, but if you're playing this game for the graphics, you're playing for the wrong reasons. The voice-acting, for an early 2000's game, is superb. The game is nearly bug-free, and the few ones can be fixed with the All In One Patch mod.

Also, this game was recently patched to run on Windows 10, so those of you with newer computers who want to relive your childhood, or those that sadly didn't have one, this game is now available for you!

Also, 6 bucks when not on sale? How can you go wrong for 6 bucks or less?

This game, even without my fond nostialgia, is by far one of my all-time favorite games I've ever played, and likely will remain so. To hell with all these new games, I'm going to be bingeing on Star Wars: Galactic Battlegrounds for months!

Seriously, if you've got 6 bucks, get this amazing game, I cannot stress how much fun this thing is, and if you're strapped for hard-drive space, the install isn't even a full gig, and the download is only around 600MB. Even with the All In One Patch, the game is still barely around 1 gig.

Great game, and if you're looking to play multiplayer, you can download GameRanger and still find a quite active playerbase to this day!
